Text: Honoré Daumier (1808-1879) was a French painter, sculptor, and printmaker. Empathizing with Les Bons Bourgeois (the urban middle class), Daumier critically depicted the tumultuous sociopolitical climate in France during the nineteenth century through his lithographs. He also illustrated scenes of everyday life amidst the chaos of the Franco-Prussian War, the siege of Paris, and political satire aimed at the government and its leaders.

Label: Le Charivari
Text: Honoré Daumier produced lithographs for Charles Philipon's political satirical journals, La Silhouette, La Caricature, and then Le Charivari. The latter was where this collection, the Album du Siège, was published in the series “Actualités” (News of the Day) between the years 1870-1871. Daumier contributed an average of 8 lithographs per month.

Label: Title Page
Text: In his Album du Siège, Daumier offers a scathing indictment of the Franco-Prussian War — caused by geopolitical tensions between the two countries and the French government's belief that a war could revitalize Emperor Napoléon III's waning popularity — and the suffering it inflicted upon ordinary people. The series is a testament to Daumier's skill as a social commentator and artist, and remains a significant work of political satire.

Daumier also focused on the suffering of civilians, particularly the famine and deprivation caused by the siege of Paris, which was a Prussian maneuver to capture the city during the climax of the war. The desperation and hunger of the Parisians is represented by a Crowned Paris eating rats.

Label: Crowned Paris
Text: Starvation and food scarcity drove civilians to not only eat rats but also cats, dogs, and even animals from the Paris Zoo. The dreadful living conditions drove Daumier to target the corrupt and ineffectual government officials who were responsible for the escalation of the siege and its disastrous consequences.

Label: Prix
Text: The entire album was priced at 5 francs during publication, although curiously, this edition is missing its price tag.

Print: Le Bombardement. Qu’estce que c’est que ça, papa? C’est le dernier bouquet des feux du 15 août.
Text: In this lithograph, Daumier depicts a scene of everyday life amidst the chaos of the Paris siege during the Franco-Prussian war.

The war had a devastating impact on Parisians as the city was besieged for several months. Parisians' lives altered dramatically during the four-month siege. The provisional “Government of National Defense” took over after the fall of Napoleon III's Empire. During this turbulent time, the food supply depleted and the economy suffered.

The lithograph portrays "The Bombardment," referencing the bombing of Paris by Prussian troops during the siege. For example, during 23 nights of bombardment in January 1871, some 12,000 shells fell on Paris neighborhoods, killing about 400 people.

The caption notes an exchange between a father and son, which translates to "What is that, dad?" The father replies, "It is the last of the fireworks of August 15." The son points towards the shelling falling over Paris.

The "fireworks" are not fireworks at all but bombs falling on the city. The dialogues's reference to a firework display on August 15 adds a layer of irony to the scene. The fireworks are reminiscent of Napoléon III's decree of moving the national holiday from the original Bastille Day on July 14 to August 15, known as La Saint-Napoléon, during his reign. The “last of the fireworks” expresses the fall of the empire and its replacement with the French Republic, under which the Paris siege occurred.
Daumier's irony in this lithograph offers a poignant critique of the provisional government’s handling of the situation and the suffering of ordinary people during the siege.
This lithograph reveals the complex nature of international relations, especially between France and England during this period.

Label: Caption
Text: “Laissez appuyer moâ sur le bras à vôs!”, translates to “Let me lean on your arm!” The response to this, “Fallait pas me laisser amputer,” translates to “Shouldn’t have let me amputate.”

Label: Question d'Orient
Text: This phrase translates to the “Eastern Question,” which is a reference to the declining stability of the Ottoman Empire in the mid-19th century. As internal attempts to reform the so-called “sick man of Europe” failed in the long-run, various European nations stood eagerly at the sides, ready to snatch up potential colonies from the crumbling Ottoman state.

Label: Albion
Text: “Albion” references the phrase “Perfidious Albion," which was a pejorative term that was frequently leveled at England due to their history of treachery and disloyalty. By the nineteenth century, the phrase became a common utterance whenever England and France had tense relations.

Label: Mars
Text: Classical imagery is abundant in Daumier’s other works. This character is Mars, the Roman god of war who is a recurring motif in Le Charivari, often symbolizing war threats. The trident adds to the allegory to England, a symbol of the nation’s mastery of the seas.

This allegorical image exemplifies the suffering of the French during the Franco-Prussian War and the impact of the five-month siege on Paris. France and the year 1871 is represented as the weeping, mother-like figure who expresses her desolation at the fate of her country.

Label: Caption
Text: “Épouvantée de l'héritage,” translates to “Dismayed by her legacy,” referencing all the chaos and bloodshed experienced by the French people because of their government's warmongering.

1871 marks the year that this print was published in Le Charivari. It also is the year after Napoléon III was deposed when the French were defeated in the disastrous Battle of Sedan. This conflict opened up the path for Prussian forces to take Paris, leading to the siege.

Label: France
Text: A grieving France is the central figure in this print. She covers her eyes, refusing to look at the sea of bodies that are scattered to the horizon line.
Honoré Daumier offers a commentary on the selfishness and indifference of those in power during this time of crisis in "Moi, je suis ravitaillé!"

Label: Moi, je suis ravitaille!
Text: In the caption, this government official states "Me, I am resupplied! The rest do not matter to me.”

This smug official, surrounded by an abundance of food and drink, represents French government officials in general during the Paris siege. The official's dismissive statement highlights the callousness and lack of empathy shown by those in positions of privilege and power, especially during times of war and scarcity.
Daumier highlights the contrast between officials' attitude and comfortable lifestyles while civilians were suffering and starving due to the exhausted food supply.

Daumier's work serves as a powerful critique of war as a destructive and futile enterprise, and a reminder of the human cost of political conflicts. His sharp social commentary and biting satire offer a powerful voice for those who suffered during this dark period in French history.
Spots of discoloration that are present in some of the lithographs are acid stains, indicating poor preservation through the years.
